Suggested CarlaStudio Processing and Troubleshooting Steps
H. Andrew Black

02-Aug-2001

Abstract

This document outlines steps you can take to more efficiently process texts and troubleshoot problems while using the CarlaStudio tool. It lists them in terms of the two major steps users usually perform: analysis and adaptation (the latter involves both transfer and synthesis).

The assumption is that you will normally be in a CarlaStudio document window.

It uses the following notations:

Program Name
The name of a program or tool used within CarlaStudio or available elsewhere on your machine.
Tab
The name of a tab section within CarlaStudio (e.g. Sample Log or Transfer).
Menu Item 1 / Menu Item 2
A sequence of menu options you can select. These may result in some dialog boxes appearing, in which case select the options indicated.

1 Analysis

  1. Make sure the processing goal of the document you are working on is to create A glossed interlinear file for the right source language (Document / Processing Goal...).
  2. Process the file (click on , the rightmost toolbar button).
  3. Check the AmpleDLL Log tab for errors (indicated by the red circle in the tab label). Fix the errors if there are any.
  4. Look for failures in the AmpleDLL Log tab.
  5. To try and fix a failure:
    1. Select the word (use the leftmost one).
    2. Copy it (e.g. use Ctrl-C or Edit / Copy).
    3. Open up or go to a QuickParse window. To create a QuickParse window, click on , the fourth tool bar button from the right.
      • Make sure the QuickParse window is for the language you are working on: Look in the title bar of the QuickParse window where it will say, "QuickParseN LanguageName" (where "N" is some number and "LanguageName" is the name of a CarlaStudio language.
      • If "LanguageName" is not the one you want to work on, use Quick Parse / Change Language until you have the right language.
    4. Paste the word into the Word or Phrase field of the QuickParse window.
    5. Check both the Include a trace in the output box and the Ask me… boxes.
    6. Press return.
    7. Select the correct set of allomorphs for the word.
    8. If it does not show an expected allomorph, check the spelling of the word and/or the set of allomorphs in the dictionary entry for the expected morpheme.
    9. If all the allomorphs are present, study the trace output. Look for the correct sequence of allomorphs. Some times, you may find that it finds the end of the word, but there is some MEC that does not work. Try to figure out what is wrong and fix any dictionary entries.
    10. Do this for all the failing words you can.
  6. Look in the Interlinear tab for any parses which are incorrect.
  7. For wrong parses, you can try and add constraints to dictionary entries to eliminate the bad ones.
  8. Contact your consultant for any failures or incorrect parses you are not able to fix.

2 Adaptation

  1. Make sure the processing goal of the document you are working on is to create A text in the target language for the right source and target languages (Document / Processing Goal...).
  2. Process the file (click on , the rightmost toolbar button).
  3. Check the Sample Log tab for any errors (indicated by the red circle in the tab label). Fix the errors.
  4. Check the Sample Log tab for any morphnames that are not in the dictionary. (Note that you must have a certain option set in the Sample processor to make these messages appear in the log file; to set this option, go to your language window and then use Language Model / Language / Synthesis Sequence...; double click on the word SAMPLE; make sure that the Check Morphnames box is checked. Click on OK twice and then go back to your document window.) These missing morphnames will be indicated by a message of the form:
    Warning: "Morphname" not found in dictionary while synthesizing word
    Add the entry for the indicated morphname.
  5. Check the Sample Log tab for any synthesis failures. Try to figure out why it is failing to synthesize. It might be because a verb entry doesn’t have a conjugation class indicated or a noun doesn’t have its paradigm class indicated. It also might be because all allomorphs are too tightly constrained.

    If it is still not clear what is wrong, create a copy of the troublesome word. To do this, first do one of the following (depending on which is appropriate for your situation):
    • If you are running from the source text file:
      1. Copy the source word as it appears in the Sample log (e.g. select it, then use CTRL-C or Edit / Copy).
      2. Create a new document window.
      3. Paste in the source word copied in the first step above (be sure to add a space at the end if you're using JoinComp or it will chop off the last character).
    • If you are running from a source ANA file:
      1. In the ZZZ ANA tab[1], find the word that is failing to synthesize (you could search for it by using Edit / Find).
      2. Select the entire \a field of the ANA record for this word.
      3. Copy the \a field (e.g. use Ctrl-C or Edit / Copy).
      4. Create a new file outside of CarlaStudio which has an extension of .ana (it does not have to have anything in it). You could use a tool like WordPad to do this.
      5. In CarlaStudio, open the file you just created (File / Open).
      6. Paste in the \a field you copied earlier (e.g. use Ctrl-C or Edit / Paste).
      7. Make sure the processing goal is to transfer from the correct source language to the right target language (Document / Processing Goal...).
    Now trace the word you copied:
    1. Trace the word (click on , the second toolbar button from the right).
    2. Look at the trace in the Sample Log tab.
    3. Find the correct allomorph for the first morpheme. Then look for where it is trying the correct allomorph of the next morpheme, and so on. When you find the form that contains all the correct allomorphs, see what constraint is failing. Fix the entry or test.
  6. Now check the ZZZ Text tab[1] and see if there are any incorrectly synthesized words or if you need to add or modify any transfer rules.
    • For those words which are incorrectly synthesized, find the word in the ZZZ ANA tab.[1] Check out the analyses and make sure they are all reasonable. Then follow the tracing procedure mentioned above. If you cannot figure it out, make a note of it and tell your consultant.
    • If the word is correctly synthesized according to the synthesis trace, but shows up with a different (and incorrect) spelling in the ZZZ Text tab[1], check the Output orthography changes (go to the target language model window, click on the Synthesis tab, and then click on Output Ortho Changes). The changes may not be correct.
    • If the word is not correctly transferred, add any appropriate transfer rules.
    • To try and debug the transfer process, perform the steps outlined in the previous step. This time, however, compare the output of the various ANA tabs.
      • The tab labeled ST-Trans ANA is the result of the SENTRANS Rules.
      • The tab labeled ZZZ ANA[1] is the result of the STAMP Lexical Changes and the STAMP Morpheme Transfer rules.
      Compare the content of the \a fields in these tabs to see how the various rules are applying. Try and fix them. If you cannot figure it out, make a note of it and tell your consultant.

Endnotes

[1]

The letters ZZZ will be whatever your language abbreviation code is.
